verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Doubtful Letters III 1:2
verses.text: A Letter of Severus to Holy Paul the Bishop.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Doubtful Letters III 1:3
verses.text: After I learned that all thy cooks had given up thy kitchen (I believe because they felt indignant at having to fulfill the duty towards cheap dishes of pulse), I sent a little boy to you out of our own workshop.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Doubtful Letters III 1:4
verses.text: He is quite skillful enough to cook pale beans and to pickle homely beet-root, with vinegar and sauce, as well as to prepare cheap porridge for the jaws of the hungry monks.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Doubtful Letters III 1:5
verses.text: He knows nothing, however, of pepper or of laser, but he is quite at home with cumin,  and is especially clever in plying the noisy mortar with sweetly smelling plants.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Doubtful Letters III 1:6
verses.text: He has one fault, that he is no kindly foe to admit to any garden; for if let in, he will mow down with a sword all things within his reach, and he will never be satisfied with the slaughter simply of mallows.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Doubtful Letters III 1:7
verses.text: However, in furnishing himself with fuel he will not swindle you.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Doubtful Letters III 1:8
verses.text: He will burn whatever comes in his way; he will cut down and not hesitate to lay hands upon buildings, and to carry off old beams from the household.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Doubtful Letters III 1:9
verses.text: We present him, then, to you, with this character and these virtues; and we wish you to regard him not as a servant, but as a son, because you are not ashamed to be the father of very small creatures.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Doubtful Letters III 1:10
verses.text: I myself would have wished to serve you instead of him; but if good-will may be taken as in some measure standing for the deed do you only, in return, take care to remember me amid your breakfasts and delightful dinners because it is more proper to be your slave, than the master of others.
